title: George Hook 'considering running for election next year'
text:
George Hook 'considering running for election next year' 21:28, 25 Oct 2015 By David Maher The presenter and pundit revealed he might try and run for Fine Gael in Dun Laoghaire-Rathdown   Thanks   Seb Daly / SPORTSFILE George Hook 
George Hook has hinted he’s considering running for the Dail next year. 
The broadcaster admitted that despite being a staunch Fine Gael supporter, he was having doubts about the party. 
And the outspoken rugby pundit revealed he has considered running in the Dun Laoghaire-Rathdown constituency for Fine Gael. 
The 74-year-old said: “I’m considering standing as a Michael Collins FG candidate, to appeal across the party-political divide to the middle classes, who see their views and beliefs are no longer represented. 
“The big three political parties in Ireland, in their rush to get elected, are united in a giveaway election campaign. 
“No doubt the success of Bertie Ahern and Brian Cowen in that regard has energised the Coalition into a belief a Budget pandering to the people’s needs for freebies will guarantee success.” 
And the broadcaster insists he would put the homelessness crisis at the top of his agenda. 
He added: “The priority is the homeless issue. It is a disgrace the fastest-growing economy in Europe can’t house its citizens. 
“The British reaction to 250,000 made homeless by the Blitz in World War II is instructive. 
“I’d demand the appointment of a TD with complete control over the issue. 
“He’d be granted extraordinary powers. Council employees would be required to work a seven-day rota to get boarded-up, empty properties back on the market. 
“There would be an immediate purchase of modular housing for urban areas to clear the backlog. 
“If Britain could clear a quarter-of-a-million backlog, surely we can do one in 700 families?” 
The radio show also said a Hook-run Government would refuse migrants from the Middle East until all Irish citizens were housed. 
He added: “I would demand that the Government give a commitment to the final figure to be accepted, rather than the interim figures which have steadily risen from 650 to 5,000.”
